72bac19ca0a2ff15f99326a8f7e02c10 (10:31): perhaps still do.
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (10:31): er, 1 year after the buy-out.
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (10:31): richlowe: they still do.
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (10:32): Apple has maintained that little HTTP directory for quite awhile. :-)
6fb06278f0acad5116524cf789d291c2 (10:32): NS has some of the most fubar'ed history of any OE possible
72bac19ca0a2ff15f99326a8f7e02c10 (10:32): hey now, 4.2BSD+mach with a DPS gui is fun!
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (10:32): phukq: OS X inherited it. :-)
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (10:32): at least from the userland perspective.
72bac19ca0a2ff15f99326a8f7e02c10 (10:32): at least OSX brought the BSD bits up to date, rather than left them languishing in the late 80's/early 90's.
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (10:32): how much of the kernel is similar, I'm not sure
6fb06278f0acad5116524cf789d291c2 (10:33): started as a Totalische company then turned to software only then got bought by Sun (who tried to bury it) then got bought by Apple
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (10:33): but given until OS X 10.2 the developer tools were *identical* to the NeXTSTEp tools.
6fb06278f0acad5116524cf789d291c2 (10:33): delewis: there's tons of methods in OS X which are named NX*
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (10:33): Jobs started NeXT
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (10:33): phukq: yes, I know.

6fb06278f0acad5116524cf789d291c2 (10:34): delewis: Jobs started NeXT on black hardware (they were making their own hardware) then NeXT gave up on hardware became software only ported NeXTSTEP to x86 and HPPA then they got bought by Sun
72bac19ca0a2ff15f99326a8f7e02c10 (10:34): x86, HPPA, and Sparc.  Though I thought the latter two were just the gui bits.
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (10:35): it was never bought by Sun.
6fb06278f0acad5116524cf789d291c2 (10:35): richlowe: you could install a full NeXTSTEP on HPPA
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (10:35): Sun invested money into NeXT to port NeXTSTEP to SPARC.
6fb06278f0acad5116524cf789d291c2 (10:37): they never bought it formally ?
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (10:38): they invested a few million dollars
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (10:40): Project Builder shipped with the OS X 10.0/10.1 developer tools :-)
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (10:40): before Xcode existed
6fb06278f0acad5116524cf789d291c2 (10:41): delewis: what about Interface Builder is it still in OS X ?
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (10:41): phukq: all of the original NeXTSTEP developer tools were included, verbatim in the OS X 10.0/10.1 developer tools.
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (10:41): Project Builder, Interface Builder, etc.
6fb06278f0acad5116524cf789d291c2 (10:42): i wonder how did NeXT manage to fubar its success so thoroughly
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (10:42): phukq: focusing on hardware.
6fb06278f0acad5116524cf789d291c2 (10:42): they could have owned the UNIX UI
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (10:42): they sucked at hardware
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (10:42): they should've stayed at software, which is where they innovated the most.
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (10:42): would've been a *perfect* time to own the UNIX UI market
6fb06278f0acad5116524cf789d291c2 (10:42): yeah they were sloooooooooooooow
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (10:42): CDE/Motif were just coming into the market
6fb06278f0acad5116524cf789d291c2 (10:42): and compared to NeXTSTEP CDE sucked
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (10:42): and obviously, NeXTSTEP would've blown them away.
6fb06278f0acad5116524cf789d291c2 (10:43): (well it still does)
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (10:43): I'm sure that's why Sun invested in NeXT in 1993 to port it to SPARC.
2b9d13217ca1d39934ebc86a4be0924f (10:43): CDE sucks on an absolute scale =P
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (10:43): as an alternative to OpenWindows, while they still weren't fully committed to CDE.
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (10:44): (CDE originated from HP Vue, which was around for a few years before0
9b40cc1e7d4e1f29c26f94aebafc409b (10:44): <3 HP Vue
9b40cc1e7d4e1f29c26f94aebafc409b (10:44): <-- old hpux guy
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (10:44): phukq: I never stated NeXT hardware was neccessarily, bad, as in technical merit.
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (10:45): but Steve had no clue about hardware production
6fb06278f0acad5116524cf789d291c2 (10:45): delewis: it wasn't bad, it was just very slow
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (10:45): and squandered most of his capital away on "perfecting" the Cube.
6fb06278f0acad5116524cf789d291c2 (10:45): Motorola 68040 is the fastest they ever got
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (10:45): not to mention he ran out of time coming to market, so they had to use the Optical drive when/where it shouldn't have been used.
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (10:46): phukq: 68040 was a fine CPU in 1987.
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (10:46): especially with the onboard DSP unit
6fb06278f0acad5116524cf789d291c2 (10:46): delewis: oh god i remember that, that was so stupid
6fb06278f0acad5116524cf789d291c2 (10:46): delewis: you had these NeXT technician guys coming in with an optical disc and booting the Cube
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (10:47): phukq: the optical concept wasn't really *that* bad, but Steve wasted so much time on perfecting the Cube, that he ran out of time to perfect other things.
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (10:47): NeXT networks were the equivalent of Sun Ray networks for the time
6fb06278f0acad5116524cf789d291c2 (10:47): delewis: but it was *so* slow it made a SPARC V7 seem like light speed
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (10:47): you walked around with your little optical disk, that contained your user-specific data
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (10:47): popped it in
6fb06278f0acad5116524cf789d291c2 (10:48): they did great multimedia for the time
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (10:48): well, regardless, they should've never bothered with hardware.
0e60fa2a21b13bc3d41902ac2acd28e3 (10:48): those optical disks had massive capacity too, iirc
6fb06278f0acad5116524cf789d291c2 (10:49): jmcp: 800MB i still have one :-)
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (10:49): NeXT would've made a killing by just selling OpenSTEP to a variety of users running various platforms and operating systems.
0e60fa2a21b13bc3d41902ac2acd28e3 (10:49): delewis: so at the time that was fairly large
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (10:49): but the drives had defects
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (10:49): slow performance, and high failure-rate.
31ea4a432844bd61233a02862fa204c3 (10:50): compared to just about everything CDE sucks
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (10:50): and of course, Apple gets all the credit nowadays for an innovative OS design, when most of the work that went into it came from NeXT. :-)
6fb06278f0acad5116524cf789d291c2 (10:50): delewis: the 22-year-old Apple fanboys don't remember NeXT :-P
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (10:50): phukq: yes, exactly, which is irritating.
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (10:51): but I try to make it a point to figure out technology legacies.
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (10:53): I vaguely recall seeing NeXT advertise in PC Mag and Computer Shopper 1995ish.
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (10:53): phukq: install the Developer Tools :-)
6fb06278f0acad5116524cf789d291c2 (10:54): delewis: and start a nostalgia/revival site ? :-)
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (10:54): write a hello, world program, then build it with the gcc-2.8 or 2.7 that the developer tools shipped. :-)
6fb06278f0acad5116524cf789d291c2 (10:55): delewis: i wrote a CD Player in NeXTSTEP in 1992 for my Master's final lab project :-)
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (10:55): OpenSTEP developer tools shipped with gcc-2.7 or 2.8 -- not sure what version the NeXTSTEP tools shipped.
2b9d13217ca1d39934ebc86a4be0924f (10:55): phukq: that's all it took back then? =P
6fb06278f0acad5116524cf789d291c2 (10:55): at that time a CD Player was considered really really advanced
6fb06278f0acad5116524cf789d291c2 (10:56): triskelios: yeah. "When I Was Your Age, We Didn't Even Have 0
6fb06278f0acad5116524cf789d291c2 (10:56): 's and 1's. we only had 0's!
